sections.title: Java
sections.description: Java Interview Questions for Automation testing

modules.title: 1. Why is Java a platform independent language?
content: Java is platform independent because Java programs are compiled into bytecode, which can run on any computer that has a Java Virtual Machine (JVM).
The compiler converts it to bytecode.
The JVM on any operating system (Windows, Mac, Linux) can run that bytecode.
So the same program runs anywhere without changing the code.

modules.title: Why is Java not a pure object oriented language?
content: Java supports primitive data types - byte, boolean, char, short, int, float, long, and double, and hence it is not a pure object-oriented language.

Non-primitive data types are complex data types that are created from primitive types or by the programmer. Examples include arrays, which store multiple values of the same type; strings, which store a sequence of characters; classes and objects, which are user-defined types containing properties and methods; and collections like lists, sets, and maps, which can hold many items together.

Non-primitive data is stored in heap memory, which is used for bigger and dynamic data, while the variable that points to this data is stored in stack memory. For example, when a string is created, the actual characters of the string are stored in the heap, and the stack stores a reference, which is the memory address pointing to the string object in the heap. Whenever the program accesses the string, it uses the reference on the stack to locate and manipulate the string object in the heap.

The stack and heap are connected through these references, meaning the stack keeps track of where the objects in the heap are located. This allows the program to efficiently manage memory: the stack handles method calls and local variables, while the heap stores complex objects that can be shared or dynamically resized during runtime.

modules.title: Difference between Heap and Stack Memory in java. And how java utilizes this.
content: Stack memory in Java is used to store local variables and function calls. It is fast and organized in a last-in, first-out (LIFO) way.
Heap memory in Java is used to store objects and non-primitive data like arrays and strings. It is bigger than stack memory and can grow dynamically.
In stack memory, variables store actual values for primitives and references (memory addresses) for objects. In heap memory, the actual objects and their data are stored.
Java uses stack memory for method execution and temporary variables, while it uses heap memory to store objects that can be accessed from anywhere in the program.
Stack and heap are connected through references. For example, a variable on the stack can point to an object in the heap, allowing the program to access and use that object.

modules.title: Why DevOps Matters2
modules.content: DevOps is important because it integrates development and operations, enabling faster and more reliable delivery of software.

modules.title: SDLC & STLC Overview
modules.content: Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) and Software Testing Life Cycle (STLC) provide structured approaches to develop and test software.

sections.title: Learning Path
sections.description: Step-by-step roadmap to become Automation & DevOps Engineer

modules.title: Java & Python Basics
modules.content: Learn the basics of Java and Python programming to start your automation journey.

modules.title: Selenium & Playwright
modules.content: Hands-on tutorials for Selenium and Playwright test automation tools.

modules.content: Understand how to structure tests using TestNG and PyTest frameworks.

modules.title: Git & GitHub
modules.content: Version control with Git and collaborating with GitHub repositories.

modules.title: Docker Fundamentals
modules.content: Introduction to Docker containers for consistent development environments.

modules.title: Jenkins Pipelines

modules.title: Selenium Framework Design
modules.content: Learn how to design a robust Selenium automation framework with best practices.

modules.title: Playwright Advanced Concepts
modules.content: Deep dive into Playwright features, cross-browser testing, and parallel execution.

modules.title: CI/CD Pipeline Walkthrough

modules.title: Docker for Test Automation
modules.content: Learn how to use Docker to containerize and run test suites efficiently.

modules.title: Build Selenium Framework
modules.content: Hands-on lab to create a Selenium automation framework from scratch.

modules.title: Playwright Automation Project
modules.content: Practical project to automate a web application using Playwright.

modules.title: Dockerize Test Suites
modules.content: Lab to package automation tests in Docker containers for consistent execution.

modules.title: Jenkins CI Pipeline Setup
modules.content: Setup Jenkins pipelines to automate test execution and deployment.

modules.title: AWS Basics for Test Engineers

modules.title: Azure DevOps Fundamentals
modules.content: Learn how to use Azure DevOps for CI/CD and project management.

modules.title: Kubernetes for Test Deployment
modules.content: Understand Kubernetes basics and deploying test environments at scale.

modules.title: Docker Swarm & Container Orchestration
modules.content: Advanced container orchestration using Docker Swarm for distributed testing.
